papers.title: International Perspectives
papers.abstract: With continuing advances in preterm baby care, survival rates are increasing in very low-birthweight (VLBW) and very low gestational age newborns in both developed countries and large centers in developing countries. Preterm babies have metabolic characteristics and many diseases and complications due to immaturity that make provision of appropriate nutrition a challenge. Even greater difficulties are encountered with microelements, known also as trace elements or oligoelements, and vitamins because basic needs are not always perfectly defined. There are also no evident clinical signs of deficiency during the neonatal period, so the neonatologist is not always aware of a need to supplement them.Several situations contribute to deficiencies in these nutrients among VLBW preterm babies: human milk fortifiers do not contain all the necessary micronutrients or contain them in insufficient quantities; formula milks have different ingredients in different countries, with the most suitable ones often not available; and formulas for parenteral nutrition do not provide the necessary micronutrients, such as selenium. Recently, supplementation of minerals such as selenium and vitamins A and E, which have antioxidant properties, has been evaluated clinically for the possible prevention of preterm infant diseases in which free radicals have pathophysiologic importance. Also, many studies have been undertaken on mineral and vitamin supplements for pregnant mothers in poorer countries that are aimed at reducing low birthweight and perinatal and infant mortality.The important microelements in human nutrition are zinc, copper, selenium, chromium, molybdenum, manganese, iodine, and iron. Although they only represent a small fraction of the human body’s total mineral content, they play important roles in various metabolic routes. Preterm babies can present with deficiencies, even without clinical signs, due to low concentrations of the elements at birth because these minerals are only incorporated in the last trimester of pregnancy.The importance of selenium increases in all ages as a component of the selenoenzymes, which have distinct functions. For example, glutathione peroxidase is an important antioxidant enzyme in cell membranes. Such enzymes prevent the formation of free radicals, reducing the lipid peroxides and hydrogen peroxide and protecting the organism from oxidative aggression. Another of selenium’s properties is its role in immunocompetence. Neutrophils and macrophages from animals deficient in selenium have low glutathione peroxidase concentrations, which can affect their antimicrobial properties. (1)(2)Selenium concentrations in the soil vary considerably in different geographic areas, and concentrations in pastures, animals, and humans reflect these variations. Concentrations in human milk follow these regional variations. (3) Human milk has much higher selenium concentrations than nonsupplemented preterm formulas. These preterm formulas, therefore, are not recommended for VLBW preterm infants.The VLBW preterm infant is vulnerable to conditions that involve an attacking free radical pathophysiology, such as bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), retinopathy of prematurity, periventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, and periventricular leukomalacia. The frequency with which such infants receive oxygen makes them susceptible to oxidative stress and the subsequent production of reactive oxygen. Although selenium deficiency may participate in such diseases in preterm babies, data to support its actual importance are lacking. In a review, Klein (1) referred to clinical studies linking selenium to diseases in preterm babies. For example, eight preterm babies who developed respiratory distress syndrome and did not receive parenteral or oral selenium experienced a rapid decrease in blood selenium concentrations 2 weeks after birth. In another study, preterm infants who had chronic lung disease (CLD) and did not receive selenium supplement experienced an accentuated decrease in selenium concentrations. In New Zealand, a country where the soil and foods are poor in selenium, low selenium concentrations in 79 VLBW preterm infants were associated with increased respiratory morbidity, and plasma concentrations were significantly lower in children dependent on oxygen at 28 days after birth. The consequences of low selenium levels in newborns have not been determined, although it has been suggested that they represent a risk factor for CLD and retinopathy of prematurity. However, there is uncertainty as to whether selenium supplementation reduces the risk of these diseases.The mechanisms that control the maternal-fetal transfer of selenium still are not fully clear. Transfer through the placenta is limited, making fetal concentrations relatively low; cord blood concentrations are about 65% those of the maternal serum. We found no significant differences in cord selenium concentrations between VLBW preterm and term newborns who were appropriate (AGA) or small for gestational age (SGA), with selenium concentrations corresponding to approximately 80% of maternal values. (4) However, Makhoul and associates, (5) evaluating cord blood selenium in newborns born between the 24th and 42nd weeks of gestation, found an association with gestational age, with a significant increase in concentration after 36 weeks.There are no data on fetal selenium content, but incorporation is estimated to be 1 mcg/kg per day. Selenium is stored in the fetal liver between gestational weeks 20 and 40, which may be why low concentrations are seen in preterm newborns. Studies of selenium concentrations in VLBW preterm infants have shown that plasma concentrations of selenium and glutathione peroxidase correlate with birthweight and that glutathione peroxidase levels in VLBW preterm newborns are one third those of term infants. (6)For preterm infants who had respiratory diseases and were receiving parenteral nutrition without selenium supplement for the first 14 postnatal days, concentrations of the element declined in the first few days after birth. (7) Except for one newborn who developed BPD, concentrations increased when feeding with selenium-supplemented formula was initiated. Other authors have shown a progressive decline in glutathione peroxidase activity in erythrocyte and plasmatic selenium in preterm newborns from the second postnatal week when fed standard milk formula.In a cross-sectional study at Botucatu School of Medicine’s Neonatal Unit, São Paulo, Brazil (UNESP), (4) we evaluated serum selenium concentrations for the first 30 days after birth in three groups of newborns: VLBW preterm, term AGA, and term SGA. From each infant we collected between two and five blood samples at different times. The infants did not receive selenium supplementation in parenteral nutrition, maternal milk with fortifier, or preterm formula. Cord selenium values were less than maternal values in all three groups. The only differences were significantly lower levels in the VLBW preterm infants on day 3 in relation to term AGA infants and an accentuated progressive decrease in selenium concentrations in preterm infants on days 15 and 30 in relation to both term groups (FigureF1). The underweight term newborns had no differences in behavior compared with the normal-weight term newborns. This study was performed in a region of São Paulo State that has average soil levels of selenium. We concluded that VLBW preterm infants require selenium supplement in both parenteral and enteral nutrition.This finding was confirmed by Darlow and associates (8) in a multicenter, randomized, double-blind trial of 534 VLBW preterm infants evaluated at 28 days after birth and 36 weeks after conception. The treatment group received 7 mcg/kg per day selenium parenterally and 5 mcg/kg per day added to maternal or formula milk. The authors observed that glutathione peroxidase and plasma selenium concentrations were significantly lower in the nonsupplemented group at both time points. This study was performed in New Zealand, which has very low soil selenium levels.In a randomized study, 38 preterm infants whose average birthweight was 1,171g received 3 mcg/kg per day selenium-supplemented parenteral nutrition and were followed for the first 6 weeks after birth. (9) They were compared with preterm infants receiving nonsupplemented parenteral nutrition and a reference group of term newborns receiving human milk or formula. Supplementation slowed selenium depletion, although they did not reach the concentrations seen with the term breastfed group, who had increased selenium levels. (9) This study also was performed in a country that has low selenium soil levels, South Australia.In the United States, Tyrala and associates (10) performed a randomized, controlled, blinded study in VLBW preterm infants. Seven infants received preterm infant formula supplemented with 3.5 mcg/100 kcal selenium, followed by term formula supplemented with 2.6 mcg/100 kcal selenium. The control group consisted of 10 children fed preterm formula with 1.2 mcg/100 kcal selenium and then a term formula containing 1.3 mcg/100 kcal selenium up to 12 weeks after birth. Plasma selenium concentrations only declined in the nonsupplemented group, although erythrocyte selenium declined in both groups. Also, glutathione peroxidase concentrations only increased in the supplemented group. The investigators concluded that selenium supplementation is required in preterm formulas. In Brazil, the same preterm infant formula was supplemented with 2 mcg/100 kcal selenium.Whether supplementation prevents diseases in newborns still requires study. In a meta-analysis by Darlow and Austin, (11) three studies fulfilled the requirements and included 297 newborns given selenium supplementation and 290 controls. Two studies included extremely preterm babies. Complications evaluated included the need for oxygen at 28 days, sepsis episodes, death while in hospital, chronic pulmonary disease (the need for oxygen at 28 d and postconceptual age of 36 wk), and retinopathy of prematurity. The authors concluded that selenium supplementation reduced one or more episodes of late-onset sepsis, but did not have a significant effect on the other diseases or complications.There is no doubt that selenium supplementation in parenteral nutrition and formulas is recommended. However, the ideal dose remains unclear. The primary question is whether umbilical cord concentrations should be the reference value, as suggested by Makhoul and associates, (5) or concentrations should be maintained similar to those in term breastfed newborns.Different quantities of selenium are used in preterm infant supplementation. The recommendation in the United States is 2 mcg/kg per day in parenteral nutrition, but meta-analysis suggests 3 mcg/kg per day is needed to maintain cord levels and much higher concentrations to attain similar levels to term breastfed newborns, as reported by Darlow and Austin. (11) A panel of specialists convened by the United States Food and Drug Administration and the American Society for Nutritional Sciences (1) recommends selenium concentrations between 1.8 mcg/100 kcal and 5.0 mcg/100 kcal in formulas for preterm infants.Zinc deficiency has been seen in suckling infants and children from developing countries who have growth and development deficiencies and immunity problems that result in increased morbidity and death from infectious diseases. (12) A randomized, controlled, double-blind study of 1,154 term undersize newborns conducted in New Delhi, India, in which the infants received zinc, vitamin, and mineral supplements from postnatal day 15, showed that only those receiving zinc had reduced mortality with a relative risk (RR) of 0.32 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.12 to 0.89 and P=0.028). (13)Keeping in mind the high prevalence of low-birthweight newborns in less developed countries and the high neonatal and infant mortality, there is worldwide interest in nutrition supplementation with micronutrients during pregnancy, primarily zinc, to reduce low birthweight. Many studies on zinc and other micronutrient supplementation during pregnancy have been undertaken in developing countries, but there are difficulties analyzing results due to different protocols, the intensity of the zinc deficiency, and differences in zinc dose and introduction time during pregnancy. (14) Some clinical studies show a reduction in the number of preterm births, increase in gestation time, and improved Apgar scores, but other researchers have not confirmed whether zinc supplementation during pregnancy affects immunocompetence, resulting in a long-term effect on mortality. Analysis of eight controlled, randomized clinical studies from less developed countries showed no beneficial effect of maternal zinc supplementation on fetal birthweight. (12)Zinc is probably the most intensely studied microelement in newborn nutrition because it is important for cell growth and differentiation. It performs various functions in protein, carbohydrate, and lipid metabolism. It also has a role in hormonal structure and genetic transcription factors. (15) Signs of subclinical zinc deficiency can occur, but they resemble those of deficiencies from other dietary components, especially if the preterm infant is receiving long-term parenteral nutrition without zinc supplement. The most characteristic signs occur after 3 months of age and include weight loss, growth difficulties, dermatitis around orifices, glossitis, and increased susceptibility to infections. (2) Preterm birth is one of the factors contributing to the appearance of deficiency, depriving the newborn of incorporated fetal zinc, similar to other micronutrients that accumulate in the third trimester of pregnancy. Such infants also have immature gastrointestinal tracts, resulting in a negative zinc balance with zinc excretion by the intestines. Studies with isotope markers have shown that the preterm infant has the ability to acquire exogenous zinc, thereby increasing absorption and reducing excretion. Preterm infants can absorb 25% to 40% of their zinc from diet. (1) In addition to less enteral absorption and less hepatic reserves, components in milk formula such as iron can affect zinc bioavailability when the iron:zinc ratio is high. Interference by iron on zinc can be seen in adults but is debatable in preterm infants. However, Klein (1) reported that formulas must use a iron:zinc ratio of 2:1, with a maximum of 3.0 mg iron to 1.5 mg zinc per 100 kcal.Because zinc bioavailability is higher in human milk than cow milk, zinc concentrations in formula should be increased. This difference in bioavailability is due to the strong binding between zinc and casein. (1) It has been shown that 60% of the zinc in preterm human milk is absorbed compared with 36% in supplemented preterm human milk and 14% in preterm infant formula. The concentration of zinc in colostrum is high, but it decreases rapidly. One month after birth, the zinc concentration of human milk is 2.5 mg/L. (15)(16)Growth is the determining factor for zinc requirements in preterm infants. Needs calculations for preterm infants between 24 and 28 weeks gestational age indicate that they need 600 mcg/d to form new tissue (excluding storing zinc) to attain comparable growth to a fetus of 40 weeks postconceptual age. Hepatic zinc liberation in a 1,000-g newborn averages 150 mcg/d. Extremely preterm infants have lower reserves, and depletion occurs earlier, around 32 to 36 weeks. Calculated dietary zinc that needs to be retained for optimal growth is 500 mcg/kg per day at approximately 1,000 g weight and 27 weeks postconceptual age, 400 mcg/kg per day for newborns weighing between 1,500 to 2,000 g (30 to 32 wk), and 200 to 300 mcg/kg per day for those weighing 2,500 to 3,500 g (35 to 40 wk postconceptual age). (1)During the transitional period (0 to 14 d), authors recommend enteral zinc intake of 500 to 800 mcg/kg per day, rising to 1 mg/kg per day when growth becomes established. (15) The recommendation for parenteral zinc intake is 150 mcg/kg per day during the transition period and 400 mcg/kg per day for stable preterm infants. (15)Considering the low absorption of ingested zinc from formulas, the specialist panel from the American Society for Nutritional Sciences in 2002 (1) recommended a minimum of 1.1 mg/100 kcal and maximum of 1.5 mg/100 kcal in formula.Literature on iron focuses more on aspects related to morbidity in the preterm infant than on nutrition. Research is directed to the prevention and treatment of anemia in prematurity.Minerals such as copper, iodine, manganese, and molybdenum have been studied in preterm infant nutrition with the aim of creating special formulas for the preterm baby and solutions for parenteral nutrition. There are few references to VLBW preterm newborns and no descriptions of the clinical manifestations linked to neonatal deficiency, which is probably why their characteristics are less reported in daily practice.Copper is an important element in enzymes such as superoxide dismutase, which protects cellular membranes from oxidative damage. Copper is stored in the fetal liver linked to metallothionein in higher quantities than in adult livers. However, it is transported from the liver to tissue by ceruloplasmin, whose concentration is low in newborns in whom production starts 6 to 12 weeks after birth. (1)(2)(15) Copper deficiency is rare in the neonatal period, but when present, causes hypochromic anemia that is resistant to treatment with iron, neutropenia, osteoporosis, skin problems, and difficulties in weight growth. Few data exist on preterm infant copper requirements. Infants fed human milk receive sufficient quantities. Long-term parenteral feeding uses 20 mcg/kg per day, which is not administered when there is cholestasis because copper is excreted by the bile duct. (15)We hope that more research will be undertaken on minerals in preterm infant nutrition so the formulas can have more balanced mineral compositions and be more adequate for the needs of extremely preterm infants who receive long-term parenteral nutrition.Vitamins, especially vitamin A and E, are among the most studied micronutrients in preterm infants. Investigations focus primarily on specific functions, such as vitamin A in the prevention of CLD/BPD in VLBW preterm infants and vitamin E for its antioxidant properties and possible action in diseases in which free radicals play an important role.There has been a recent resurgence of studies on vitamin supplements for pregnant mothers, aimed not only at reducing intrauterine, fetal, and neonatal infections, but also pregnancy complications such as pre-eclampsia and preterm birth. A physiologic basis and some clinical and in vitro studies have supported these investigations. In intrauterine infection, an important cause of preterm birth, local inflammatory reaction produces proinflammatory cytokines and reactive oxygen species, indicating oxidative stress, and vitamins that have antioxidant properties such as vitamin C and E can prevent oxidative damage in the chorionic membranes and premature membrane rupture. (17) Free radicals play a role in vascular alterations in pre-eclampsia, and high concentrations of lipid peroxidation markers, such as malondialdehyde, are seen in pregnant women who suffer pre-eclampsia. Additional studies have documented a reduced incidence of pre-eclampsia in patients receiving vitamin C and E supplements, (18) although contradictory results were shown in a 25-center, randomized, placebo-controlled trial in the United Kingdom of 2,410 women at risk of pre-eclampsia. (19) The pregnant women received 1,000 mg vitamin C and 400 IU vitamin E from the fourth month of pregnancy. The incidence of pre-eclampsia was similar between groups, and there was a higher incidence of low-weight births in the supplemented group. The authors concluded that vitamins C and E had no impact on preventing pre-eclampsia. We await the results of new ongoing studies. (19).The term vitamin A refers to a group of compounds formed by retinol, retinaldehyde, and retinoic acid. Retinol, the most studied of the three, comes directly from animal-originated foods or is formed in the organism from beta-carotene metabolism. In the liver, it is linked to retinol-binding protein (RBP), which is transported through plasma bound to transthyretin. Ninety percent of retinol is stored in the liver, with the rest found in tissues such as the retina and lung.In the fetus, vitamin A has a role in cell differentiation and lung growth. In the VLBW preterm newborn, low vitamin A reserves associated with low RBP concentrations causes lower plasma concentrations than in term newborns. Vitamin A deficiency is considered by many authors to be a contributing factor to the development of CLD and BPD, primarily in extremely preterm infants.Since the first studies showing that plasma vitamin A concentrations were much lower in preterm newborns who developed BPD, it was obvious that supplements were necessary for VLBW preterm infants, especially those whose birthweights were less than 1,000 g, who are at high risk of developing CLD/BPD.Studies of vitamin A supplementation in preterm infants suggest that values higher than 20 mcg/dL (0.7 mcmol/L) indicate vitamin A sufficiency. Extremely low-birthweight newborns at risk of vitamin A deficiency present with low retinol concentrations. Low values of vitamin A correspond with plasma concentrations less than 20 mcg/dL (0.7 mcmol/L), and vitamin A deficiency is represented by plasma concentrations less than 10 mcg/dL (0.35 mcmol/L). (20) However, the relationship between plasma vitamin A concentration and its functional state is not clear, (21) and many healthy preterm infants have concentrations below 20 mcg/dL (0.7 mcmol/L) during their stays in the neonatal unit.For preterm infants, the American Academy of Pediatrics (1998) recommends vitamin A administration corresponding to 210 to 450 mcg/kg per day of retinol (1 mcg of equivalent retinol=3.3 IU). (20) According to Shenai, (22) ingestion of less than 700 IU/kg per day (<210 mcg/kg per day) is associated with an accentuated decline in plasma vitamin A concentration, and ingestion of more than 1,500 IU/kg per day (>450 mcg/kg per day) normalizes plasma retinol values. It is doubtful whether these values are sufficient for extremely low-birthweight preterm infants. According to Landman and associates, (23) high doses (5,000 IU/d) of vitamin A with early enteral nutrition in VLBW preterm infants can cause plasma retinol concentrations similar to those from intramuscular doses (2,000 IU on alternate days). However, Wardle and associates (24) found that, due to the difficulties in administering nutrients by the enteral route in extremely low-birthweight preterm infants, high vitamin A doses administered enterally from birth may not increase plasma concentrations significantly or improve the clinical picture. Therefore, questions still exist as to the best method of supplementing vitamin A in VLBW preterm infants.Considerable vitamin A is lost when administered by the parenteral route in a dextrose and amino acid solution because of photo-oxidation (approximately 16% lost) and tube absorption (approximately 59% lost), suggesting that only 38% of the quantity administered parenterally is effective. Administering retinyl palmitate together with lipid increases this effectiveness to 90%. The American Society for Clinical Nutrition recommends a minimum parenteral dose of 280 mcg/kg per day for preterm newborns. (25)Knowledge of the importance of vitamin A in lung epithelial cell differentiation has led to the assumption that high vitamin A doses can prevent CLD/BPD in VLBW preterm infants. Ten randomized, controlled trials were evaluated in a Cochrane Systematic Review by Darlow and Graham. (26) The primary objective was to evaluate the influence of vitamin A supplementation on mortality and morbidity, including CLD, BPD, and retinopathy of prematurity. Only five trials met the eligibility criteria, resulting in 141 children treated with vitamin A supplement and 141 not treated. Results of the meta-analysis showed that high vitamin A doses did not influence mortality in the first postnatal month, but there was a tendency to reduce dependency on oxygen therapy. Vitamin A did affect combined death and oxygen dependency. In this meta-analysis, vitamin A supplementation did not always maintain circulating retinol concentrations above deficiency levels.Tyson and associates, (27) in a multicenter, randomized, blind trial of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Neonatal Research Network, evaluated 807 extremely low-birthweight preterm infants who needed respiratory support 24 hours after birth and were given vitamin A supplement corresponding to 5,000 IU intramuscularly three times a week for 4 weeks. The mean weight of the infants was 770 g in the vitamin A group and 769 g in the control group at 26.8 and 26.7 weeks’ gestation, respectively. The primary outcome, death or CLD at 36 weeks postconception, was less frequent in the treated group (55% versus 62%). Also, the proportion of infants who had serum retinol levels below 20 mcg/dL (0.70 mcmol/L) was 25% in the vitamin A group versus 54% in the control group.A study in extremely low-birthweight preterm infants who received higher doses of vitamin A (10,000 IU three times a week or 15,000 IU once a week) found no significant differences compared with a standard retinol dose (5,000 IU three times a week) in the incidence of death/BPD or death at 36 weeks postconception. (28) The authors recommended the standard regimen.A review article by Mactier and Weaver (21) reported that elevated doses of vitamin A administered by the intramuscular route three times per week in the first postnatal week had not been used widely. Limiting factors were the large number of intramuscular injections against the modest results in the respiratory system, the consequent pain, and the invasiveness of the procedure. They considered vitamin A by parenteral route together with lipid to be superior to oral vitamin A for extremely low-birthweight infants and questioned why there had been no comparisons between the parenteral route with lipid and the intramuscular route. They reported that many neonatal units administer supplements orally as soon as initiating enteral nutrition and that the recommended dose is 4,000 IU/kg per day.Few services in Brazil have adopted supplementation by intramuscular route. Our service routinely uses oral supplementation at 5,000 IU/d for VLBW preterm infants after the first week from the time they receive full enteral feeding. To evaluate retinol concentrations in VLBW preterm infants submitted to this feeding regimen, we prospectively evaluated plasma retinol by high-performance liquid chromatography from blood obtained from 22 mothers at the moment of delivery and from their respective infants up to 28 days of age. (29) The infants were divided into two groups according to whether they had BPD. Seventy-two percent of the mothers had received antenatal steroid treatment. We evaluated plasma retinol in the function of estimated vitamin A received over different periods in both groups. Vitamin A estimates were: 173 IU/dL for mother’s milk + fortifier, 240 IU/dL for preterm formula, 920 IU/kg per day for vitamin A by parenteral route with lipid, and 5,000 IU/d for oral vitamin A. The TableT1 shows the results. Maternal concentrations were 54.61 mcg/dL (1.91 mcmol/L) in the BPD group and 46.90 mcg/dL (1.64 mcmol/L) in the non-BPD group. The concentrations in both newborn groups remained similar to their umbilical cord values, except on the 14th day, when both groups had maximum peak values of 59.88 mcg/dL (2.1 mcmol/L) in the BPD group and 40.40 mcg/dL (1.41 mcmol/L) in the non-BPD group. Additionally, retinol values were high in the BPD group on the 28th day. Vitamin A administration was similar for both groups (500 IU/kg per day for the non-BPD group and 700 IU/kg per day for BPD group) in the first week. Vitamin A administration in the non-BPD group was exclusively by enteral route at an average of 3,606 IU/kg per day from the second to fourth week and in the BPD group was 868 IU/kg per day for the second week exclusively by parenteral route and 1,660 IU/kg per day in the third and fourth weeks, with 20% by the parenteral route. Average birthweights were 1,180±265 g for the non-BPD group and 1,097±201 g for the BPD group, with respective gestational ages of 30.5 and 28.5 weeks. Only 15% of the infants weighed less than 1,000 g. Vitamin A concentrations below 20 mcg/dL (0.7 mcmol/L) were found in only 18% of newborns, most on the third day, when they were starting parenteral nutrition. (29)We concluded that in 1,000- to 1,500-g birthweight newborns, parenterally administered vitamin A with lipid followed by high doses by gastric route produced elevated retinol concentrations for the non-BPD group on the 14th day and for the BPD group on the 14th and 28th days. Because cord and third postnatal day concentrations were adequate when supplementation was low, it is possible that the hepatic reserves of these infants were normal and, therefore, supplementation doses were excessive. Due to the small sample, we could not make conclusions about the influence of vitamin A on BPD frequency. (29)A different result was reported by Wardle and associates (24) in a randomized, controlled trial of 154 preterm infants whose birthweights were less than 1,000 g and whose mothers received antenatal steroid. The infants received 5,000 IU/kg per day of vitamin A from day 1 by orogastric tube. Their plasma vitamin A values were significantly higher only 24 hours after birth, but at birth, 12 hours, 7 days, and 28 days after birth, they were not different from controls. Also, 50% of the oral vitamin A group had plasma concentrations below 20 mcg/dL (0.7 mcmol/L) at 28 days of age. There were no differences in CLD incidence or other clinical outcomes.We conclude that for extremely preterm infants whose plasma retinol concentrations are low in whom supplementation by gastric route is not viable, the best option is the intravenous or intramuscular route.Vitamin E is comprised of a group of eight biologically active tocopherols. The most active, alpha-tocopherol, makes up 90% of the vitamin E found in human tissue. The commercial forms, alpha-tocopherol acetate or succinate, are more stable than natural alpha-tocopherol. The standard equivalent international unit for biologic activity is 1.0 mg of alpha-tocopherol. (30)(31)Vitamin E is found in all tissues, where it serves as an antioxidant and free radical scavenger. It blocks natural peroxidation of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) found in lipid layers of cellular membranes. Peroxidation starts when an atom of hydrogen escapes the double bond of one of the carbons, causing an intermediate situation that is highly favorable to reaction with an oxygen free radical. The consequent lipid free radical interacts with another PUFA, creating a stable lipid hydroxyperoxide, and another free radical, causing a chain reaction. Vitamin E blocks this chain reaction by substituting the oxygen in the reaction and stabilizing the hydrogen reaction of the lipid free radical. In this fatty acid peroxidation inhibition process, alpha-tocopherol is transformed into alpha-tocopheryl quinone, which is excreted in urine as malondialdehyde, pentane, and ethane.Because 90% of the tocopherol pool is located in adipose tissue, and preterm newborns have less adipose tissue, they have less vitamin E reserves. Also, these reserves are not easily available. Low vitamin E concentrations are found in fetal tissue and increase toward the end of gestation with the addition of fat. Plasma concentrations of tocopherol vary, depending on the quantity of lipids, due to their association with lipoproteins. Therefore, it is better to express concentration in relation to beta-lipoprotein, cholesterol, or total lipids. An alpha-tocopherol/total lipids ratio less than 0.8 mg/g indicates a vitamin E deficiency. (30)Vitamin E concentrations in colostrum and preterm human milk is two times higher than in mature term milk. (30) During the first postnatal week it contains 1.9 IU/100 kcal, representing a vitamin E:PUFA ratio of 2.0. The quantity decreases to about 0.9 IU/kcal during the fourth postnatal week. Preterm babies fed their own mother’s milk and preterm formulas containing vitamin E maintain sufficient concentrations. However, authors consider that before attaining full enteral nutrition feedings, vitamin E must be supplied in parenteral nutrition at doses of 2.8 to 3.5 IU/kg per day to maintain alpha-tocopherol plasma concentrations at 1 to 2 mg/dL. (32) Preterm formulas generally are supplemented with 4.0 to 6.3 IU/100 kcal with a vitamin E/PUFA ratio of 3.83 to 3.98. (1) In 2002, the Expert Panel of the American Society for Nutritional Sciences recommended that vitamin E content in preterm formulas be a minimum 2 mg and maximum 8.0 mg alpha-tocopherol/100 kcal. The vitamin E/PUFA ratio (mg alpha-tocopherol/g total PUFA) must exceed 1.5 mg/g.Studies using high vitamin E doses have shown that toxic effects can occur. In addition to the well known cases in which death occurred in preterm infants who received 25 to 100 mg/kg per day tocopherol acetate in polysorbate intravenously, there are also reports of increased sepsis and enterocolitis with intravenous or oral administration associated with plasma tocopherol levels of 4.8 mg/dL.Brion and associates (31) performed an important systematic review of vitamin E supplementation in preterm infants and the prevention of morbidity and mortality. It included 26 randomized, controlled clinical trials from which the most important conclusions for VLBW preterm newborns were that vitamin E supplementation did not affect mortality, risk of BPD (except for a small group analyzed for persistent ductus arteriosus), and risk of matrix hemorrhage/intraventricular hemorrhage and necrotizing enterocolitis. The authors observed an increased risk of sepsis in VLBW newborns (RR 1.53; CI 1.13, 2.08) in four studies involving 400 treated patients and 407 controls. They observed that the risk was higher when the vitamin E dose was more than 30 IU/kg per day and serum tocopherol concentrations were greater than 3.5 mg/dL. In the presence of retinopathy of prematurity, vitamin E supplementation reduced the risk of a severe magnitude of disease and blindness, but only when serum vitamin E concentrations were higher than 3.5 mg/dL. The authors considered that, for VLBW newborns, the evidence was against using high doses of vitamin E supplementation by parenteral route or supplementation that elevated serum levels above 3.5 mg/dL (81.3 mcmol/L). They considered that American Society for Clinical Nutrition recommendations for extremely low-birthweight preterm infants (2.8 to 3.5 IU/kg per day) should be the standard for preterm infants fed parenterally.Defining the various vitamin needs of preterm newborns has become very complex as industrial formulations have taken over this function. There are vitamin solutions for parenteral use, supplementation formulas for preterm infants, and fortifiers for human milk. There are also excellent reviews by specialists from groups of American, Canadian, and European Societies attempting to define the requirements for enteral and parenteral routes and the maximum and minimum levels for preterm infant formulas. We, therefore, give some of the most commonly cited indications from literature, which can help the neonatologist to decide how to administer these micronutrients.Two review articles on vitamin K for newborns (32)(33) indicate that preterm infants receiving parenteral nutrition, preterm infant formulas, or human milk fortifiers containing vitamin K do not need additional supplementation. For newborns who are not being fed these formulations or who might be fed human milk exclusively, which is very low in vitamin K, a prophylactic dose of vitamin K may prevent the classic hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. In a meta-analysis, (34) the prophylactic postnatal administration of vitamin K reduced clinical bleeding at 1 to 7 days and improved biochemical indices of coagulation. There was no difference between oral and intramuscular routes on biochemical indices of coagulation at 1 to 7 days. (34) The prophylactic recommendation is an intramuscular dose of 1.0 mg phylloquinone for infants whose birthweights are greater than 1,000 g and 0.3 mg for those weighing less than 1,000 g. Prophylactic administration of vitamin K1 remains standard practice for the prevention of hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, although the procedure is not uniform. Some countries employ an oral regimen of three doses of 1.0 to 2.0 mg, with the first dose after birth, the second after 2 to 4 weeks, and the third at 8 weeks.With the exception of vitamin C, few data exist about the needs and functions of these vitamins, especially for extremely preterm infants who receive prolonged parenteral nutrition. Because they are soluble in water, excessive doses are excreted by the kidneys, and maximum tubular reabsorption occurs with low doses.L-ascorbic acid scavenges superoxide and hydroxyl radicals. Vitamin C can play an important role in extremely preterm infants experiencing hyperoxia whose antioxidant defenses are very low. Additionally, the oxidant function of vitamin C in the presence of iron in vitro has been described. Research results differ as to vitamin C concentrations in newborns who have BPD. In a randomized, controlled, double-blind study of newborns weighing less than 1,500 g, Darlow and associates (35) reported no influence of high vitamin C concentrations equivalent to 30 mg/kg per day versus 10 mg/kg per day by parenteral route only on evaluating oxygen needs at 28 days after birth and 36 weeks postconception as well as the presence of retinopathy of prematurity. The recommended vitamin C doses for extremely preterm infants are between 20 and 50 mg/d enterally and between 20 and 40 mg/d parenterally. (32) The Expert Panel of the American Society for Nutritional Sciences recommended that the minimum concentration of vitamin C be 8.3 mg/100 kcal and the maximum concentration 37.0 mg/100 kcal for preterm infant formulas. (1)Trace elements and vitamins are being given more importance in the nutrition of pregnant women in poorer regions of developing countries due to their antioxidant and immunocompetence properties. Investigations of zinc and vitamin A, E, and C supplements for pregnant mothers have examined reducing low birthweight; intrauterine, fetal, and neonatal infections; and maternal gestation complications.The antioxidant properties of trace elements and vitamins are extremely important in the nutrition of VLBW preterm infants, who are vulnerable to diseases in which free radical aggression plays an important role. Investigations have shown that VLBW preterm infants need supplements high in vitamin A to reduce the incidence of CLD/BPD. Selenium is an important supplement in parenteral and enteral nutrition of VLBW infants because it is a component of glutathione peroxidase, an enzyme that protects the organism from oxidative aggression. Vitamin E supplementation for extremely low-birthweight infants is still a matter of discussion. More controlled, randomized studies are needed to determine the real importance and best methods of supplementing microelements and vitamins for disease prophylaxis in preterm infants.

papers.title: [Endocrine and other medical causes of abnormal fatigability].
papers.abstract: Many endocrine diseases can cause fatigue. Tiredness is a frequent symptom of primary and secondary hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, excessive glucocorticoid or mineralocorticoid production, primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency, primary and secondary hypogonadism and hyperprolactinemia in the male, acromegaly, diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus. A great number of medical diseases other than those mentioned in the articles on cardiological and pneumological fatigue can also cause abnormal tiredness (infectious diseases, hematological, renal, hepatic, gastrointestinal and rheumatological disturbances, vasculitis and malignant tumors). The pathogenesis of tiredness caused by endocrine or medical illnesses, i.e. how the sensation of fatigue is produced, is not clear. The fatigue of the various endocrine or other medical diseases is not disease-specific, i.e. its characteristics do not differentiate it from the fatigue of other illnesses.

papers.title: The importance and dosage of amino acids in nutritional support of various pathological conditions in ICU patients
papers.abstract: Normal adults require twenty L-amino acids (AA) for protein synthesis. Functional AA regulate key metabolic pathways that are necessary for maintenance, growth, reproduction and immunity. Dietary supplementation with one or a mixture of these AA may be beneficial for ameliorating health problems at various stages of the life cycle and for optimizing of the efficiency of metabolic transformations. During disease, other amino acids also become essential. The principal goal of protein/amino acid administration in various pathological conditions in intensive care unit (ICU) patients is to provide the precursors of protein synthesis in tissues with high turnover and to protect skeletal muscle mass and function. Amino acid requirements in parenteral nutrition (PN) are higher when the patient is stressed/traumatized/infected than in the unstressed state. In severely ill ICU patients a higher provision of protein and amino acids has been associated with a lower mortality.An overview of the effects and dosage of amino acids in nutritional support of various pathological conditions in ICU patients is presented.It was demonstrated that 2.0-2.5 g protein substrate/kg normal body weight/day is safe and could be optimal for the most critically ill adults to decrease the risk of morbidity and mortality in some pathological conditions.

papers.title: Simple Intestinal Obstruction: Prolongation of Life for 45 Days with Parenteral Alimentation
papers.abstract: The length of survival of dogs having a low simple intestinal obstruction depends upon the ability to maintain fluid, electrolyte, and nutritional requirements. By parenteral alimentation with the methods used adequate nutritional requirements were not obtained, but in 1 animal in which these requirements were approached more closely the length of survival was 45 days.

papers.title: Megaloblastic Anaemia
papers.abstract: Megaloblastic anaemia is usually due to deficiency of vitamin B12 (B12, cobalamin) or folate. Both deficiencies impair DNA synthesis by reducing the supply of deoxythymidine triphosphate which provides thymine, one of the four bases in DNA. Vitamin B12 is present only in animal foods and is absorbed by gastric intrinsic factor facilitating its entry into the ileal enterocyte. Deficiency is usually due to malabsorption, most commonly pernicious anaemia, but it also occurs in strict vegetarians or vegans. Folate is present in most foods and absorbed through the upper small intestine. Body stores are low in relation to daily needs and deficiency occurs due to a poor diet alone or combined with a condition such as pregnancy or haemolytic anaemia where requirements are increased. The anaemia is identical in the two deficiencies but vitamin B12 deficiency can also cause a neuropathy affecting peripheral nerves and the spinal cord. Both deficiencies in pregnancy are associated with an increased incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus and infancy. Genetic abnormalities of the proteins involved in vitamin B12 or folate absorption or transport are also associated with megaloblastic anaemia and, for B12 , a neuropathy.

papers.title: Evaluación del tamizaje selectivo de errores innatos del metabolismo en el Instituto Materno Infantil en Colombia
papers.abstract: El programa de deteccion de Errores Innatos del metabolismo del Instituto Materno Infantil (IMI) de Bogota, en un periodo de cinco anos ha estudiado 1.147 pacientes de alto riesgo (nacidos y remitidos al IMI como tambien procedentes de otras Instituciones) con: 1.Antecedentes en la historia familiar 2.Alteraciones neurologicas. 3.Sepsis sin respuesta al tratamiento. 4.Asfixia perinatal severa, falla cardiaca, dificultada respiratoria sin causa evidente. 5.Alteracion de la funcion hepatica. 6.Hipoglicemia persistente. 7.Acidosis metabolica con brecha anionica aumentada. 8.Retardo de crecimiento intrauterino. 9.Dismorfismo, olor raro. 10.Presentacion anormal del cabello. 11.Falla para crecer. 12.Intolerancia, dificultad en la alimentacion.

papers.title: MENURUNKAN INFLAMASI PASIEN SLE DAN GIZI BURUK DENGAN SUPLEMENTASI MIKRONUTRIEN
papers.abstract: Latar Belakang Lupus eritematosus sistemik (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)(SLE) merupakan penyakit inflamasi autoimun kronis dengan etiologi yang belum diketahui serta manifestasi klinis. Laporan Kasus Nn.M, Perempuan, 20 Tahun dikonsul dengan bagian penyakit bagian Interna divisi Ginjal Hipertensi untuk evaluasi dan penatalaksanaan gizi serta rawat bersama dengan diagnosis medis Sistemik Lupus Eritematosus dan anoreksia Asupan makan berkurang dialami sejak 2 minggu yang lalu karena tidak ada nafsu makan. Mual ada setiap kali makan, muntah tidak ada, nyeri ulu hati ada, demam tidak ada, riwayat demam ada terutama malam hari, badan lemas,tidak mampu berdiri maupun duduk sendiri, batuk ada sejak 2 minggu, lendir ada. Penurunan berat badan ada ±4 kg dalam 2 minggu(BB dulu 35 kg). Asupan 24 jam 97,5 kkal. Pasien didiagnosis dengan status gizi buruk, status metabolik anemia (Hb 6,2 g/dl), deplesi berat sistem imun (TLC 400/uL), Hipertrigliseridemia 236 mg/dl, risiko refeeding, hipoalbumin berat 2.2 g/dl dan status gastrointestinal fungsional. Penatalaksanaan nutrisi dengan target awal energi 2000 kkal, oleh karena pasien dengan resiko refeeding maka dilakukan penatalaksanaan nutrisi 10-15 kkal/hari selama 3 hari dengan pemberian thiamin 300 mg/hari serta perbaikan kadar kalium darah. Setelah terlewati 3 hari , nutrisi dinaikkan sesuai toleransi pasien sampai 2500 kkal dengan komposisi protein 2 gr/kg BBI/hari(16%), karbohidrat 60%, lemak 24% melalui oral berupa makanan lunak sesuai toleransi, formula nutrican, jus buah tinggi kalium, madu, dan olive oil, zink 20 mg/24 jam, Ca hydrogen phosphate 400 mg, Ca laktat 200 mg, Vitamin B6 40 mg, Vitamin C 50 mg, Vitamin D3 200 IU, fish oil(EPA) 2000 mg/24 jam, ekstrak ikan gabus 3 kapsul/8 jam. Setelah 15 hari perawatan, status gizi buruk dengan perbaikan pasien secara klinis(IMT 14,5 kg/m2), hemoglobin 10.7 g/dl, deplesi berat sistem imun (TLC 600/uL), hipoalbumin ringan 3.1 gr/dL. Kesimpulan Dukungan nutrisi optimal dapat membantu untuk mengendalikan inflamasi yang ditemukan akibat penyakit SLE dan komplikasi yang disebabkan efek samping pengobatan.

papers.title: Sindrom Refeeding pada Neonatus
papers.abstract: Refeeding syndrome (SR) adalah sekelompok gejala yang terjadi setelah pemberian nutrisi enteral atau parenteral pada pasien kekurangan gizi. Angka kejadian SR bervariasi yaitu hipofosfatemia 20–90%, hipokalemia 8,8–66,7%, dan hipomagnesemia 1–8,3%. Faktor risiko SR meliputi neonatus dengan kecil masa kehamilan (KMK), pertumbuhan janin terhambat (PJT), bayi berat lahir sangat rendah (BBLSR), prematur ekstrim, umbilical artery resistency index (UARI) tinggi, atau berat badan menurut panjang badan berdasarkan z-score <-2 standar deviasi (SD). Pemberian asam amino tinggi pada awal kehidupan secara bermakna dapat meningkatkan risiko SR termasuk hipofosfatemia berat pada BBLASR. SR dapat dicegah dengan melengkapi pemberian elektrolit (khususnya fosfat) pada awal pemberian nutrisi.

papers.title: Clinical manifestations of chronic atrophic gastritis.
papers.abstract: Although the actual prevalence of chronic atrophic gastritis is unknown and it is probable that this entity goes largely underdiagnosed, patients in whom diagnosis is established usually present advanced stages of disease. Destruction of parietal cells, either autoimmune-driven or as a consequence of Helicobacter pylori infection, determines reduction or abolition of acid secretion. Hypo/achloridia causes an increase in serum gastrin levels, with an increased risk of the development of neuroendocrine tumors. Microcytic, hypochromic anemia frequently precedes the development of megaloblastic, vitamin B12-associated anemia. Moreover, vitamin B12 deficiency,may cause elevation of homocysteine, with an increase in the cardiovascular risk, and may be associated with neurological manifestations, mainly characterized by spinal cord demyelination and atrophy, with ensuing sensory-motor abnormalities. Gastrointestinal manifestations seem to be associated with non-acid reflux and tend to be non-specific.

papers.title: Inferior Vena Cava Occlusion and Protein-losing Enteropathy After Liver Transplantation in Children
papers.abstract: Protein-losing enteropathy (PLE) in children can occur as a result of protein loss from abnormal intestinal lymphatics or across an inflamed or abnormal intestinal mucosal surface (1). Protein-losing enteropathy secondary to abnormalities of intestinal lymphatics, or intestinal lymphangiectasia, may be primary or acquired (1). Important physiologic mechanisms in the pathogenesis of PLE caused by abnormal lymphatic protein loss include 1) intraatrial obstruction of the systemic venous return, leading to high constant systemic venous pressure and impeding the lymphatic flow into the superior vena cava, for example, after Fontan procedure (2,3); 2) damage to the thoracic duct; and 3) obstruction of hepatic venous outflow, such as in Budd-Chiari syndrome (4). Protein-losing enteropathy caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow after liver transplantation has been reported previously (4). There are no previous reports of PLE associated with inferior vena cava obstruction after liver transplantation. We report two children in whom PLE developed with and without intestinal lymphangiectasia because of inferior vena cava obstruction after liver transplantation. CASE REPORT Case 1 An 18-month-old boy underwent liver transplantation for fulminant hepatic failure secondary to non-A, non-B hepatitis. He underwent retransplantation 3 months later for chronic graft rejection. During the second liver transplantation, he received a segment 2 to 4 liver graft. The donor inferior vena cava was anastomosed to the recipient inferior vena cava above and below the liver graft. Four years after the second liver transplantation, the patient had hypoalbuminemia (serum albumin, 24 g/L; normal, 35–50 g/L) on routine follow-up. Physical examination revealed no lymphadenopathy or ascites, and associated diarrhea was not reported. Full blood count showed a hemoglobin concentration of 98 g/L, a white cell count of 4.9 × 109/L, a lymphocyte count of 0.9 × 109/L, and a platelet count of 143 × 109/L. The urine tested negative for protein. Serum immunoglobulin (Ig) G, IgA, and IgM concentrations were within normal ranges, whereas IgG subclass 2 concentration was low (0.3 g/L; normal range, 0.7–1.5 g/L). Protein-losing enteropathy was confirmed by increased fecal α-1-antitrypsin concentration (11.6 mg/g dry fecal weight; normal range, <5 mg) and by increased chromium-labelled albumin recovered in the feces over 5 days (54.2%; normal, <5%). Doppler ultrasound showed an enlarged spleen and no abnormality of hepatic vessels. Investigations for posttransplant lymphoproliferative disease, including abdominal computer tomography scan, were negative. A barium meal showed edema of the small intestinal wall. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showed esophageal varices and a small prepyloric ulcer. A jejunal biopsy specimen showed intestinal lymphangiectasia without villous atrophy. A liver biopsy specimen showed established fibrosis, without pericentrilobular necrosis. The diagnosis was PLE secondary to acquired intestinal lymphangiectasia, presumed secondary to the operative technique at liver transplantation. For the next 6 years, the patient experienced hypoalbuminemia (serum albumin, 17 g/L), edema, ascites, and recurrent infections, including pneumococcal and Escherichia coli septicemia. He received albumin infusions and a medium-chain triglyceride (MCT)–based diet, spironolactone (1mg/kg body weight 3 times/day), and a weekly immunoglobulin (Gamimune) infusion, which was gradually decreased to once every 3 weeks. He disliked nasogastric feeding and the MCT-based diet, and considerable psychologic difficulties developed. He had an emergency admission 6 years after the onset of PLE for high fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain. The patient was ill and malnourished, with peripheral edema, distended and tender abdomen, and enlarged liver and spleen. Serum albumin concentration was 17 g/L, and coagulation was deranged. Bacterial peritonitis was diagnosed, and he began therapy with antibiotics and with albumin and immunoglobulin infusions. He refused abdominal paracentesis. Eventually he underwent abdominal ultrasound. The retrohepatic inferior vena cava was not visualized. A portovenography performed 2 weeks later confirmed the stenosis of the inferior vena cava at the anastomosis between recipient and donor inferior vena cavae. Hepatic and portal veins within the liver graft were patent. An aneurysmal dilatation of the inferior vena cava was visible below the liver graft, and flow was reversed in the donor inferior vena cava, which was diverted through the azygous system and azygous vein into the superior vena cava. Pressure within the donor inferior vena cava, below the occlusion and hepatic vein, was 33 mm Hg. A 5F catheter was advanced through the right internal jugular vein into the superior vena cava. The occlusion was punctured from above the site into inferior vena cava, which was subsequently dilated with a 12-mm balloon. The patient became hemodynamically unstable. Respiratory and hepatorenal failure and irreversible sepsis developed, and the patient died 3 days after the procedure. Case 2 A 10-year-old boy underwent liver transplantation for type II autoimmune hepatitis. The inferior vena cava anastomosis was achieved using a piggyback technique. Chronic liver graft rejection and recurrence of autoimmune hepatitis developed, and the patient underwent retransplantation 10 months later. Four months after the second liver transplantation, a right-sided pleural effusion developed, without ascites. Culture results of the pleural fluid were negative, and the protein was 49 g/L, suggesting an exudate. At 14 years of age, 3 years after the second liver transplantation, the patient experienced asymptomatic ankle edema. He had bilateral pleural effusions and ascites, without lymphadenopathy. Veins on the abdominal wall were distended. Complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, and liver enzyme concentrations were normal. Plasma albumin concentration was 19 g/L, total bilirubin concentration was 7 μmol/L. There was no proteinuria. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy results were normal. The liver had increased echogenicity, but all hepatic vessels were patent. The direction of splenic blood flow was normal. The spleen was enlarged to 14.4 cm. Radioisotope albumin scan confirmed PLE, showing albumin leakage from the small intestine. A small bowel biopsy specimen showed edema of the gut, with no dilatation of lacteals. Computer tomography scans of the abdomen showed edema of the small bowel mesentery and subcutaneous fat. There was no lymphadenopathy. The retrohepatic portion of the inferior vena cava was occluded with thrombosis, confirmed with hepatic venography and cavography. The guide wire was passed through the occlusion with difficulty (Fig. 1).FIG. 1.: Inferior venacavogram immediately after a guide wire was advanced successfully across the occluded segment of the inferior vena cava (labeled 1). The guide wire tip is now in the right heart. Venogram shows filling of numerous venous collaterals including an enlarged azygos vein (labeled 2) as a result of caval occlusion.The patient began a low-fluid, low-salt, MCT-based diet and spironolactone therapy (5 mg/kg body weight). A portovenogram showed a patent portal venous system. The mean pressure in the superior mesenteric vein, splenic vein, recipient portal vein, extrahepatic donor portal vein, and intrahepatic portal vein was 7 mm Hg. There was an occluded segment of the inferior vena cava between the ostia of the hepatic vein and the right renal vein (Fig. 1). Recanalization of the occluded inferior vena cava and stenting were performed using a 7F sheath to advance an Amplatz stiff wire and transjugular biopsy needle though the occluded segment (Fig. 2). The balloon was then dilated, and two overlapping Jomed stents were placed. Warfarin therapy, 1 mg twice daily, was begun.FIG. 2.: Inferior venacavogram after successful stent placement across the occluded inferior vena cava (labeled 3) shows excellent flow through the stented inferior vena cava. There is no flow through collateral veins because of reestablished caval flow into the right atrium. Right renal pyelogram (labeled 4) is shown because of the normal renal excretion of intravascular radiologic contrast.Peripheral edema and ascites resolved within 1 month after placement of the inferior vena cava stent. The plasma albumin concentration increased to 31 g/L. All supportive therapy and the MCT-based diet were discontinued. A repeat ultrasonic examination 6 months later showed a patent inferior vena cava with no evidence of thrombus in the region of the stent or in the junction between the hepatic veins and the right atrium. The patient has remained well 9 months after the procedure. DISCUSSION Vascular thrombosis is a well-known complication after liver transplantation, especially in children (5). Thromboses of the hepatic artery or portal vein at the anastomosis between the recipient and the donor vessels is most common (6,7). Thrombosis of the inferior vena cava after liver transplantation is rare because of the large caliber of the vena cava (5), although Brouwers et al. (8) reported a 2.5% incidence of post–liver transplantation inferior vena cava obstruction caused by compression or torsion of the inferior vena cava. Oliguria was a common complication after inferior vena cava thrombosis, but PLE was not observed (8). The fact that in both patients, inferior vena cava thrombosis developed after a second transplant suggests the role of inferior vena cava interruption and subsequent anastomosis as a predisposing factor in inferior vena cava thrombosis after liver transplantation in children. We report two cases of inferior vena cava obstruction after liver transplantation that led to PLE. In the first case, the clinical picture was similar to Budd-Chiari syndrome (9), with obstruction of the inferior vena cava in the suprahepatic portion at the anastomosis between the recipient and donor inferior vena cavae, which obstructed the hepatic vein outflow. Currently, liver transplantation of segmental grafts should be performed using only the piggyback technique, because this technique is associated with better posttransplant outcome (10). However, the first child underwent liver transplantation in 1988, before development of this technique. After transplantation, portal hypertension, cirrhosis, ascites, and acquired intestinal lymphangiectasia developed. Doppler ultrasound was delayed for this child because of major psychological and social problems, resulting in poor compliance with rigorous follow-up. Tsuchiya et al. (11) described PLE secondary to Budd-Chiari syndrome in a 26-year-old man who had a membranous web above the hepatic vein entrance into the inferior vena cava, and thrombosis of the inferior vena cava below the hepatic vein ostia. Endoscopy and a biopsy specimen showed evidence of intestinal lymphangiectasia. The PLE regressed after membranotomy of the web. The authors concluded that microcirculatory disturbances of blood flow in the bowel caused by portal hypertension of Budd-Chiari syndrome led to PLE (11). This might have been the cause of intestinal lymphangiectasia and PLE in the first case report. The second patient had no endoscopic evidence of portal venous hypertension, and the mean portal venous pressure was less than 10 mm Hg. The hepatic vein outflow was not obstructed. However, venography showed evidence of venous collaterals involving the azygous venous system (Fig. 1). Small bowel mucosa edema also was present, although there was no histologic evidence of intestinal lymphangiectasia. Collateral circulation develops after partial and complete obstruction of the inferior vena cava (12). In middle inferior vena cava obstruction between the renal and hepatic veins, collateral circulation had been shown to develop between the inferior hemorrhoidal plexus of the internal iliac venous system with the superior hemorrhoidal vein, the inferior mesenteric vein, and the portal vein (13). Therefore, although no portal hypertension occurred in the second case, increased portal blood flow may have occurred as a result of collaterals developing after inferior vena cava obstruction. This increased portal blood flow led to bowel mucosal edema and abnormal albumin leaking and to eventual PLE. A similar mechanism may be responsible for PLE secondary to inflamed small bowel mucosa in inflammatory bowel disease (2). The clear temporal association between successful stenting of the occluded inferior vena cava and resolution of hypoalbuminemia and edema supports this. Treatment options for thrombosis of the inferior vena cava are limited (14). Venous bypass surgery has been the only option but has limited efficacy and applicability (15). This surgery was not indicated in either patient because both underwent liver transplantation and inferior vena cava anastomosis, which would have made inferior vena cava reconstructive surgery technically difficult. Endovascular stent placement has emerged recently as an effective treatment option for inferior vena cava stenoses and occlusions, and has an encouraging medium-term outcome (16). The second patient in the current report, who underwent successful stenting, showed an encouraging result 6 months after the initial procedure. Risks with using the Amplatz stiff wire and transjugular biopsy needle include pulmonary embolism. However, in the absence of other alternatives for this patient, the risk involved was deemed acceptable. The first patient underwent balloon dilatation of the occluded inferior vena cava while experiencing recurrent septicemia, and hemodynamic instability developed soon after a successful balloon dilatation. The occurrence of septicemia after stenting may be secondary to infectious thrombosis. Therefore, carefully monitoring cardiovascular status and aggressive management of sepsis before the procedure are important. In conclusion, systemic venous occlusion with inferior vena cava obstruction after liver transplantation is uncommon but may lead to PLE with or without intestinal lymphangiectasia. Early diagnosis and therapy is necessary to prevent long-term complications. Recanalization of the occlusion may be successful, but stenting may be required.

papers.title: Nutrición en el lactante con enfermedad hepática crónica
papers.abstract: Resumen El deterioro nutricional del lactante con enfermedad hepatica cronica (EHC) es secundario principalmente a problemas en la ingesta, absorcion y excrecion de alimentos. Presentan compromiso del indice peso para la edad (P/E) y talla para la edad (T/E), principalmente. Igualmente, estos pacientes presentan alteraciones importantes en cuanto a los paraclinicos como hipoalbuminemia y anemia. Como se ha reportado en la literatura mundial, en las EHC, se observa un compromiso de los niveles de vitaminas liposolubles, con un mayor compromiso de las vitaminas A y E. [Caro TS, Velasco CA. Nutricion en el lactante con enfermedad hepatica cronica. MedUNAB 2005; 8 (1 Supl 1):S55-S58] Palabras claves: Enfermedad hepatica cronica, Nutricion, Lactantes, Ninos

papers.abstract:
OSSZEFOGLALAS: Az etkezesi zavarok, mint peldaul az anorexia nervosa es a
bulimia nervosa, negatv hatassal lehetnek a sportolok teljesitmenyere es egeszsegi

allapotara. A sportolok a nem sportolokhoz kepest mind a nők, mind a ferfak veszelyez-
tetetek etkezesi rendellenesseg kialakulasara. Ez kulonosen igaz az olyan sportagakban

reszt vevő sportolokra, ahol az alacsony testomeg vagy karcsusag versenyelőnyt jelent.

Az eveszavaroknak harom fő tpusa (anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, falaszavar) mel-
let a sportolok koreben az anorexia athletca is megjelenik. Az eveszavarban szenvedő

sportolok sportol valo eltltasa javasolt. Az etkezesi rendellenessegek megelőzesere ira-
nyulo erőfesziteseket a sportolokra, az edzőkre, a szulőkre es a sportolokkal foglalkozo

szakemberekre kell iranyitani, es az egeszseges taplalkozas ismereteinek egyseges kiter-
jesztesere kell osszpontositani a sporteljesitmeny es az egeszseg tamogatasa erdekeben.

Kulcsszavak: eveszavar, anorexia athletca, izomdiszmorfa
ABSTRACT: Eatng disorders,such as anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa, can
have a negatve impact on athletes ’performance and health. Athletes, compared
to non-athletes, both women and men have risk for having an eatng disorder. This is

especially true for athletes in sports where low weight or slimness is a compettve ad-
vantage. There are 3 main types of eatng disorders (anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa,

binge eatng disorders), even anorexia athletca appears among athletes. Athletes who

vent eatng disorders should be directed to athletes, coaches, parents and professionals

working with athletes, and should focus on uniformly broaden knowledge of healthy
eatng to support athletc performance and health.

papers.title: POLIOENCEFALOMALACIA EM RUMINANTES
papers.abstract: Polioencefalomalacia e uma enfermidade metabolica, podendo ser definida como um conjunto de alteracoes na estrutura do sistema nervoso central, observadas macroscopicamente e microscopicamente. A sintomatologia esta intimamente atrelada ao deficit de energia produzida pelas celulas nervosas devido a falta de tiamina ou mesmo outras causas como o excesso de enxofre, intoxicacao por chumbo e intoxicacao por sal devido a privacao de agua. O diagnostico pode ser realizado terapeuticamente. Ruminantes em confinamento sao os mais acometidos por esta enfermidade, sendo que a prevencao pode ser embasada no controle eficaz de uma boa alimentacao, livre de tiaminases e com a quantidade de enxofre dentro do tolerado pela especie.

papers.abstract: 尽管遗传代谢性肝病在临床上并不多见,但因其在遗传性代谢病中占有重要位置,所以越来越受到人们重视.这类疾病通常指由于遗传性酶缺陷所致物质中间代谢紊乱,主要表现肝脏形态结构和(或)功能上病变,常伴有其他脏器的损害.目前认为这类肝病的发生机制有:酶缺陷导致代谢底物或衍生物蓄积,代谢产物减少或缺如,正常的次要代谢途径开放产生的副产品蓄积,膜转运功能异常,反馈抑制作用消失,药物代谢异常等等。

papers.title: The Hiddean Hunger
papers.abstract: Pediatricians have becoming familiar not very infrequentlywith the scenario that an apparently healthy child beingtested for a complete blood count for other clinicalconditions showing moderate to very low Hb% level, laterdiagnosed due to Iron deficiency. When the fact is exposedthe parents reacts with an exclamation because of theirstatement have been offering very nutritious foods (e.g.meats, eggs, polaou / biriany, very costly items from luxuryrestaurants and JUNC foods etc) to their kids, thennutritional anemia occurred. This is one of the verycommon examples of Hidden Hunger in mid-incomegroups. The cause of this condition in the children belongsto low income group is obvious. The children who are not growing and as well as notdeveloping well, are the victims of apparently silent butsteadily progressing, of the three strands of the tripleburden of Malnutrition that is rapidly emerging incommunities around the world. Globally almost 200hundred million children under 5 suffer from stunting,wasting, or both and at least 340 million from hiddenhunger of vitamin and mineral deficiencies. At the sametime, 40 million children under 5 are overweight and thetoll from overweight and obesity keeps rising, even inlower-income countries. These patterns reflect a profoundtriple burden of malnutrition that threatens the survival,growth and development children and nations
